author: Ramin Setoodeh
title: ‘Fantastic Beasts’ First ‘Harry Potter’ Movie to Win an Oscar | Variety
text:
Courtesy of Warner Bros. February 26, 2017 | 07:23PM PT 
Hogwarts fans can finally forgive the Academy. The “ Harry Potter ” franchise, with one of the most stubborn losing streaks in the telecast’s history — 12 nominations over eight prior movies — finally clenched its first Oscar on Sunday night for “ Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them .” SEE MORE: Awards: The Contenders 
The Warner Bros. tentpole, a prequel written by J.K. Rowling, landed the best costume design statue for its 20th century creations made by Colleen Atwood. While the latest movie isn’t set at the famous “Harry Potter” school, it features a cast — led by Eddie Redmayne as a Magizoologist with a briefcase packed with animals — that exists in the same universe. Related Academy Award Winners 2017: Updated List 
“That’s shocking,” said Atwood, when asked backstage by a Variety reporter about breaking the curse. “There’s so much incredible artistry in the ‘Harry Potter’ movies.” She paused for a moment to consider what might have changed. “I think maybe the fact that this movie, J.K. Rowling’s creation, is set in the 1920s, which keyed off a different visual sense, is the obvious thing.” 
“I can’t believe they never won for the incredible clockwork of Stuart Craig’s,” she added, referring to the “Potter” production designer. 
The “Harry Potter” series is the second-most successful franchise of all time, grossing $8.5 billion worldwide since 2001. Filed Under:
